page.title: 02LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: The area is dotted with detached isolated farms surrounded by out buildings. Most houses and old buildings are made of cob, but newer sheds are of building blocks or corrugated iron with a corrugated iron roof. Close to each farm there is usually a tall, steel silo for the storage of grain or feed. Apart from these the landscape hasn't been much affected. The farm houses are usually off the road, down a long track or drive and are often invisible to the passer-by. The only church in the block is a now disused Methodist chapel which is up for sale. Ashbury Plantations are mainly coniferous areas of well-managed woodland but there are also some areas of deciduous trees which are badly run down and the trees are dead or dying. There are also pockets of scrub or marsh.
